title: Pediatric Blood Pressure Distributions
text: default method estimating blood pressure percentiles based method Martin, DeWitt, Scott, et al. (2022) Martin, DeWitt, Albers, et al. (2022) uses three different references depending age known/unknown stature. want use specific reference can using source argument. project want/need use specific source ’d use can set option: four sources: Gemelli et al. (1990) kids one year age. Lo et al. (2013) kids three years age height unknown. Expert Panel Integrated Guidelines Cardiovascular Health Risk Reduction Children Adolescents (2011) kids 1 18 years age known stature. Flynn et al. (2017) kids 1 18 years age known stature. data Flynn et al. (2017) Expert Panel Integrated Guidelines Cardiovascular Health Risk Reduction Children Adolescents (2011) similar one major difference. Flynn et al. (2017) excluded overweight obese ( BMI 85th percentile) children. example, estimated percentile blood pressure 92/60 39.2 month old female 95th height percentile : estimated 85th quantile SBP/DBP 39.2 month old female, 95th height percentile :
code: options(pedbp_bp_source = "martin2022")  # default d <- data.frame(source = c("martin2022", "gemelli1990", "lo2013", "nhlbi", "flynn2017"),                 p_sbp = NA_real_,                 p_dbp = NA_real_)  for(i in 1:nrow(d)) {   bp <- p_bp(q_sbp = 92, q_dbp = 60, age = 39.2, male = 0, height_percentile = 95, source = d$source[i])   d[i, "p_sbp"] <- bp$sbp   d[i, "p_dbp"] <- bp$dbp } d ##        source     p_sbp     p_dbp ## 1  martin2022 0.4612040 0.7950359 ## 2 gemelli1990        NA        NA ## 3      lo2013 0.4703190 0.7017401 ## 4       nhlbi 0.4612040 0.7950359 ## 5   flynn2017 0.4623641 0.7698042 d <- data.frame(source = c("martin2022", "gemelli1990", "lo2013", "nhlbi", "flynn2017"),                 q_sbp = NA_real_,                 q_dbp = NA_real_)  for(i in 1:nrow(d)) {   bp <- q_bp(p_sbp = 0.85, p_dbp = 0.85, age = 39.2, male = 0, height_percentile = 95, source = d$source[i])   d[i, "q_sbp"] <- bp$sbp   d[i, "q_dbp"] <- bp$dbp } d ##        source    q_sbp    q_dbp ## 1  martin2022 103.5868 62.31975 ## 2 gemelli1990       NA       NA ## 3      lo2013 102.4425 64.30968 ## 4       nhlbi 103.5868 62.31975 ## 5   flynn2017 104.0844 62.83117

title: Overview of Growth Standards
text: Using Percentile Data Files LMS values provided CDC, Child Growth Standards provided World Health Organization (), provide tools finding quantiles, percentiles, z-scores, following metrics: BMI age head circumference age height age length age weight age weight height weight length lengths/heights centimeters, ages months, weights kilograms. Stature used refer height length; specific methods provided .

title: Overview of Growth Standards
text: methods use published LMS parameters define z-scores, percentiles, quantiles skewed distributions. L λ\lambda parameter, Box-Cox transformation power; MM median value, SS generalized coefficient variation. given percentile z-score, corresponding physical measurement, X,X, defined X={M(1+λSZ)1λλ≠0Mexp(SZ)λ=0.X = \begin{cases}    M \left(1 + \lambda S Z \right)^{\frac{1}{\lambda}} & \lambda \neq 0 \\    M \exp\left( S Z \right) & \lambda = 0. \end{cases} can get z-score given measurement X:X: Z={(XM)λ−1λSλ≠0log(XM)Sλ=0. Z = \begin{cases}   \frac{\left(\frac{X}{M}\right)^{\lambda} - 1}{\lambda S} & \lambda \neq 0 \\   \frac{\log\left(\frac{X}{M}\right) }{ S } & \lambda = 0.   \end{cases} Percentiles determined using standard normal distribution z-scores. eight noted methods provide distribution function, quantile function, function returns z-scores.

title: Overview of Growth Standards
text: growth standard metrics quantile, distribution, z-score function naming convention (q_<metric>), (p_<metric>), (z_<metric>), respectively. Additionally, function gs_chart building growth standard charts percentile curves, gs_cdf plotting cumulative distribution function given set inputs. Example Find distribution value 13 year (156 month) old male BMI 21. easy way visualize BMI distribution use growth standard chart  cumulative distribution function  can also easily get z-score instead distribution value. Find median BMI quantile 48 month old female :
code: ## [1] 0.8006439 ## [1] 0.8006439 0.8541621 gs_chart(metric = "bmi_for_age", male = 1, source = "CDC") +   ggplot2::geom_point(x = 13 * 12, y = 21, inherit.aes = FALSE) ## Error in get(paste0(generic, ".", class), envir = get_method_env()) :  ##   object 'type_sum.accel' not found gs_cdf(metric = "bmi_for_age", male = 1, age = 13*12) +    ggplot2::geom_point(x = 21, y = p_bmi_for_age(21, male = 1, age = 13*12)) z_bmi_for_age(q = 21, male = 1, age = 13*12) ## [1] 0.8439234 q_bmi_for_age(p = 0.5, male = 0, age = 48) # default is CDC ## [1] 15.32168 q_bmi_for_age(p = 0.5, male = 0, age = 48, source = c("CDC", "WHO")) ## [1] 15.32168 15.26020

title: Pediatric Blood Pressure
text: Blood pressure percentiles based Gaussian distributions defined published values mean standard deviation, derived mean standard deviations based published percentiles. Growth standards based LMS approximations. methods get parameters based lookup tables.

title: Pediatric Blood Pressure
text: several data sources used inform blood pressure percentiles estimates: Gemelli et al. (1990) Lo et al. (2013) NHLBI/CDC (2011) Flynn et al. (2017) default method use workflow defined Martin, DeWitt, et al. (2022).  End users may opt use single data source. Example: 28 month old female stature 92 cm recorded blood pressure 95/50. Find percentiles. Selecting source data also possible can also find quantile values. Example: SBP/DBP values 42nd percentile 13 year (156 month) old males 90th height percentile? examples can found vignette.
code: library(pedbp) p_bp(q_sbp = 95, q_dbp = 50, male = 0, age = 28, height = 92) p_bp(q_sbp = 95, q_dbp = 50, male = 0, age = 28, height = 92, source = "martin2022")  # Default p_bp(q_sbp = 95, q_dbp = 50, male = 0, age = 28, height = 92, source = "gemelli1990") p_bp(q_sbp = 95, q_dbp = 50, male = 0, age = 28, height = 92, source = "lo2013") p_bp(q_sbp = 95, q_dbp = 50, male = 0, age = 28, height = 92, source = "nhlbi") p_bp(q_sbp = 95, q_dbp = 50, male = 0, age = 28, height = 92, source = "flynn2017") q_bp(p_sbp = 0.42, p_dbp = 0.42, age = 156, male = 1, height_percentile = 0.90) vignette("bp-distributions", package = "pedbp")

title: Pediatric Blood Pressure
text: Growth standards based CDC data provided package. Read vignette Growth standards implemented package : * bmi_for_age * head_circumference_for_age * Stature Age * height_for_age * length_for_age * weight_for_age * Weight Stature * weight_for_length * weight_for_height
code: vignette(topic = "growth-standards", package = "pedbp") # Example: what is the percentile for a BMI of 23 in a 14.5 year old male? p_bmi_for_age(q = 23, male = 1, age = 14.5*12, source = "CDC") ## [1] 0.8502674 p_bmi_for_age(q = 23, male = 1, age = 14.5*12, source = "WHO") ## [1] 0.8880632

title: BMI for Age - Pediatric Growth Standard — bmi_for_age
code: # The 54th quantile BMI (kg * m^(-2)) for a six year (72 month) old female # is bmi <- q_bmi_for_age(p = 0.54, male = 0, age = 72.0) all.equal(p_bmi_for_age(q = bmi, male = 0, age = 72), 0.54) #> [1] TRUE all.equal(z_bmi_for_age(q = bmi, male = 0, age = 72), qnorm(0.54)) #> [1] TRUE  # Find the 29th percentile for females from ages 0 through 6 years in three # month increments.  Sourcing the only CDC will generate a warning; # suppressed in this example. ages <- seq(0, 72, by = 1) bmi_29 <-   data.frame(     age = ages   , "CDC"     = suppressWarnings(q_bmi_for_age(p = 0.29, male = 0, age = ages, source = "CDC"))   , "WHO"     = q_bmi_for_age(p = 0.29, male = 0, age = ages, source = "WHO")   )  plot(     x = bmi_29$age   , y = bmi_29$WHO   , col = 1   , pch = 16   , xlab = "Age (months)", ylab = "29th percentile BMI (kg * m^(-2))"   , type = "b" ) points(x = bmi_29$age, y = bmi_29$CDC, col = 2, pch = 17, type = "b") legend("bottomright", col = 1:2, pch = 16:17, legend = c("WHO", "CDC"))

title: Pediatric Blood Pressure Distribution — bp_distribution
text: pedbp_bp object.  list two numeric vectors systolic diastolic pressure respectively. names vectors depends call.  p_bp returns list vectors names: sbp_p dbp_p.  q_bp returns list vectors names: sbp dbp.  z_bp returns list vectors names: sbp_z dbp_z. Additionally, pedbp_bp object bp_params attribute provides details data source parameters used estimates.

title: Pediatric Blood Pressure Distribution — bp_distribution
text: source used specify method source data sets distributions estimated.  can controlled option pedbp_bp_source. End users encouraged set option using default calls functions use source. Options: martin2022 (default) uses combination references generate   distribution values ages 1 months 18 years, without without known   stature.  method implemented version 1 pedbp package. gemelli1990 uses reference values Gemelli et al.   (1990).  values applicable patients 1 month 12 months   age. Stature used look parameters. lo2013 uses reference values Lo et al. (2013).   applicable patients least three years age.  Height   considered looking parameters. nhlbi uses reference values National Heart,   Lung, Blood Institute [NHLBI] Centers Disease Control   Prevention [CDC] published 2011.  patients least one   year age known stature.  values publish flynn2017 uses reference values Flynn et al. (2017).   values similar nhlbi values _but_ "include children   adolescents overweight obesity (ie, BMI >= 85th   percentile). hierarchy use height, height_percentile, default_height_percentile.  height provided, takes precedence two arguments. height_percentile used height missing takes precedence default_height_percentile.  height needed using nhlbi flynn2017 data sources (including part martin2022 workflow).

text: numeric vector

title: Distribution, Quantile, and Z-scores by LMS values — distribution-quantile-zscores-by-lms
text: parameters need either length 1 equal length. L power Box-Cox transformation, M median, S generalized coefficient variation. given standard score (z-score), Z, value X interest $$ X = \begin{cases} M (1 + LSZ)^{1/L} & L \neq 0 \\ M \exp(SZ) & L = 0. \end{cases} $$ get z-score value X: $$Z = \begin{cases} \frac{ \left(\frac{X}{M}\right)^{L} - 1 }{LS} & L \neq 0 \\ \frac{\log\left(\frac{X}{M}\right)}{S} & L = 0. \end{cases}$$

title: Distribution, Quantile, and Z-scores by LMS values — distribution-quantile-zscores-by-lms
text: Cole, Timothy J., Pamela J. Green. "Smoothing reference centile curves: LMS method penalized likelihood." Statistics medicine 11.10 (1992): 1305-1319.

title: Distribution, Quantile, and Z-scores by LMS values — distribution-quantile-zscores-by-lms
code: l <- -0.1600954 m <-  9.476500305 s <-  0.11218624  # the 5th quantile: qlms(x = 0.05, l = l, m = m, s = s) #> [1] 7.900755  # What percentile is the value 8.2? plms(x = 8.2, l = l, m = m, s = s) #> [1] 0.09599727  # What is the standard score for the value 8.2 zlms(x = 8.2, l = l, m = m, s = s) #> [1] -1.304701  all.equal(   zlms(x = 8.2, l = l, m = m, s = s)   ,   qnorm(plms(x = 8.2, l = l, m = m, s = s)) ) #> [1] TRUE  # get all the quantiles form the 5th through 95th for a set of LMS parameters ps <- seq(0.05, 0.95, by = 0.05) qs <- qlms(x = ps, l = l, m = m, s = s) all.equal(plms(qs, l, m, s), ps) #> [1] TRUE all.equal(zlms(x = qs, l = l, m = m, s = s), qnorm(ps)) #> [1] TRUE

title: Estimate Normal Distribution Given Set of Quantile Values — est_norm
text: X ~ N(mu, sigma), Pr[X <= q] = p Given set quantiles probabilities, est_norm uses optim (method = "L-BFGS-B", lower = c(-Inf, 0), upper = c(Inf, Inf)) find preferable mean standard deviation normal distribution fit provided quantiles. Use weight argument emphasize , , provided quantiles needs approximated closer others.  default quantiles weighted equally.

title: Estimate Normal Distribution Given Set of Quantile Values — est_norm
code: # Example 1 q <- c(-1.92, 0.1, 1.89) * 1.8 + 3.14 p <- c(0.025, 0.50, 0.975)  x <- est_norm(q, p) str(x) #> List of 5 #>  $ par    : Named num [1:2] 3.31 1.72 #>   ..- attr(*, "names")= chr [1:2] "mean" "sd" #>  $ qp     : num [1:3, 1:2] -0.316 3.32 6.542 0.025 0.5 ... #>   ..- attr(*, "dimnames")=List of 2 #>   .. ..$ : NULL #>   .. ..$ : chr [1:2] "q" "p" #>  $ weights: num [1:3] 1 1 1 #>  $ call   : language est_norm(q = q, p = p) #>  $ optim  :List of 5 #>   ..$ par        : num [1:2] 3.31 1.72 #>   ..$ value      : num 8.73e-05 #>   ..$ counts     : Named int [1:2] 7 7 #>   .. ..- attr(*, "names")= chr [1:2] "function" "gradient" #>   ..$ convergence: int 0 #>   ..$ message    : chr "CONVERGENCE: REL_REDUCTION_OF_F <= FACTR*EPSMCH" #>  - attr(*, "class")= chr "pedbp_est_norm" x #>     mean       sd  #> 3.312550 1.721361   plot(x)   # Example 2 -- build with quantiles that are easy to see unlikely to be from # a Normal distribuiton q <- c(-1.92, 0.05, 0.1, 1.89) * 1.8 + 3.14 p <- c(0.025, 0.40, 0.50, 0.975)  # with equal weights x <- est_norm(q, p) x #>     mean       sd  #> 3.469290 1.563764  plot(x)   # weight to ignore one of the middle value and make sure to hit the other x <- est_norm(q, p, weights = c(1, 2, 0, 1)) x #>     mean       sd  #> 3.621388 1.551445  plot(x)   # equal weight the middle, more than the tails x <- est_norm(q, p, weights = c(1, 2, 2, 1)) x #>      mean        sd  #> 3.3200002 0.3552437  plot(x)

title: Stature for Age - Pediatric Growth Standard — p_height_for_age
code: # Find the first quartile height for a 66 month old female. # The quantile based on CDC data is slightly less than the quantile based on # the data from the WHO q_height_for_age(p = 0.25, age = 66, male = 0, source = c("CDC", "WHO")) #> [1] 107.6194 108.8470  # The 90th quantile length/height for a 24 month female: note that these # values are similar, but not identical q_length_for_age(p = 0.9, age = 24, male = 0, source = c("CDC")) #> [1] 89.79282 q_height_for_age(p = 0.9, age = 24, male = 0, source = c("CDC")) #> [1] 89.40951  # Find the percentile for a 28 month old male with a stature (height/length) # of 88 cm p_height_for_age(q = 88, male = 1, age = 28, source = "CDC") #> [1] 0.3730417 p_height_for_age(q = 88, male = 1, age = 28, source = "WHO") #> Warning: age/stature below lower limit #> [1] NaN p_length_for_age(q = 88, male = 1, age = 28, source = "CDC") #> [1] 0.2944436 p_length_for_age(q = 88, male = 1, age = 28, source = "WHO") #> [1] 0.2325074  # correseponding standard scores z_height_for_age(q = 88, male = 1, age = 28, source = "CDC") #> [1] -0.323808 z_height_for_age(q = 88, male = 1, age = 28, source = "WHO") #> Warning: age/stature below lower limit #> [1] NaN z_length_for_age(q = 88, male = 1, age = 28, source = "CDC") #> [1] -0.5404492 z_length_for_age(q = 88, male = 1, age = 28, source = "WHO") #> [1] -0.7306143

title: pedbp 2.0.0
text: includes name change “vital signs” “growth standards” complete redo methods implemented extended data sources Use terms “percentile”, “distribution”, “probability” robust. v1 “percentile” referred terms. Now, percentile implies value 0 100, distribution (value) probability, denoted p, values 0 1.

title: pedbp 2.0.0
text: Added features blood pressure distribution functions functions gain argument source specify reference values used generate percentiles. Default martin2022 keep functionality version 1. Add new source blood pressure percentiles called flynn2017 referencing Flynn, Joseph T., David C. Kaelber, Carissa M. Baker-Smith, Douglas Blowey, Aaron E. Carroll, Stephen R. Daniels, Sarah D. De Ferranti et al. “Clinical practice guideline screening management high blood pressure children adolescents.” Pediatrics 140, . 3 (2017). Implementation moved c++ speed improvement compared version 1 huge. v2 200 times faster v1. Add z_bp return z-scores blood pressure; complement existing q_bp p_bp methods. Create S3 method bp_cdf plotting #9 Extended growth chart distribution data source include CDC (v1.0.0) World Health Organization () New “growth-standards” vignette Add gs_chart building growth standard charts Add gs_cdf building growth standard cumulative distribution functions Add bp_chart building blood pressure charts Rebuild Shiny application use new features v2.0.0

title: pedbp 2.0.0
